overview_metadata.overview_subtitle: Determining Experimental Probability of Simple Events
overview_metadata.overview_description: In this lesson, students flip a coin, toss a cup, and spin a spinner to calculate experimental probabilities. They observe how more trials bring experimental probability closer to theoretical probability, use percent error for comparison, and apply proportional reasoning to predict outcomes.

overview_item_data_items: I can predict the experimental probability of a chance event by collecting data in a probability experiment.
I can construct a probability model using frequencies in data generated from a probability experiment.
I can use proportional reasoning to determine the theoretical probability of random events.

Experimental probability is the ratio of the number of times an event occurs to the total number of trials performed: <math><msub><mi>P</mi><mi>e</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>number</mi><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>of</mi><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>times</mi><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>the</mi><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>event</mi><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>occurs</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>total</mi><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>number</mi><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>of</mi><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>trials</mi><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>performed</mi></mrow></mfrac></math>.

Theoretical probability is the ratio of the number of desired outcomes to the total possible outcomes: <math><msub><mi>P</mi><mi>t</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>number</mi><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>of</mi><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>desired</mi><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>outcomes</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>total</mi><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>possible</mi><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>outcomes</mi></mrow></mfrac></math>.

Percent error, <math><mfrac><mrow><msub><mi>P</mi><mi>e</mi></msub><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>P</mi><mi>t</mi></msub></mrow><msub><mi>P</mi><mi>t</mi></msub></mfrac><mo>â‹…</mo><mn>100</mn></math>, is one way to measure the difference between experimental and theoretical probabilities.
You cannot calculate the experimental or theoretical probability for some situations.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio:
Students calculate the probability of each outcome and compare the calculated and actual probabilities.
Materials: Coins (1 per pair)

Students determine the experimental and theoretical probability.
Materials: Cups (1 per pair)

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_title: Predicting Theoretical Probability Using Experimental Probability
overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio:
Students calculate the experimental probability for outcomes on a spinner to predict the theoretical probability.
Materials: Paper clips (1 per pair)
Students analyze the percent error of theoretical and experimental probabilities.
Students determine whether they can calculate each probability experimentally, theoretically, or both.

overview_item_data_items: To avoid printing additional materials not included in MATHbook (like Activate activities and Session Quick Checks) project them using the Present button above.
